awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Wafer-Scale, Defect-Free Assembly of Three-Dimensional Plasmonic Nanoarchitectures
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports research that contributes fundamental new knowledge in the manufacturing of three-dimensional functional nanoarchitectures with applications in light manipulation, thus promoting basic science and technology in the fields of plasmonics and advanced manufacturing. Guided manipulation of light through periodic patterns of three-dimensional plasmonic nanoarchitectures provides remarkable opportunities to harness light in a way that cannot be obtained with conventional optics. However, its practical implementation remains challenged by the low-yield, time-consuming, and limited scalability of conventional fabrication processes that largely rely on the use of nanolithography. This research studies a new nanomanufacturing process based on three-dimensional nanoassembly to fabricate the plasmonic nanoarchitectures. The integration of three-dimensional nanoarchitectures with diverse substrates is increasingly preferred for broad applications in imagers, sensors and lasers, which greatly benefits the U.S. economy and society. The project is multidisciplinary and involves mechanics, optics and advanced nanomanufacturing. It provides excellent educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and fosters interest in science and engineering in women and under-represented minority groups. 

The fabrication of three-dimensional (3D) plasmonic nanoarchitectures largely relies upon the utilization of conventional nanolithography techniques that involve the use of either electron-beam, focused ion-beam, or beam interference. However, significant challenges exist in adopting these conventional techniques for diverse substrates including flexible or curved surfaces, especially, since they are principally designed to form nanopatterns on the flat surface of radiation-sensitive materials with the assistance of thermal or chemical post-treatments. This research is to develop a new nanomanufacturing technique that achieves deterministic assembly of 3D plasmonic nanoarchitectures on suitable receiver substrates in a way that allows the donor wafer to be reused for cost-savings. The process involves the use of water under ambient conditions without additional need of chemical, thermal or mechanical treatments, thereby substantially extending the type of receiver substrate to arbitrary materials. The collaborative research involves experiments to elucidate critical controlling parameters and underpinning solid-liquid interactions supported by multiscale/multiphysics computation modelling to predict manufacturing process parameters and their control with integration of atomistic simulation. The 3D plasmonic nanoarchitectures are integrated with hybrid pixel imagers to demonstrate the enhancement of their detection functionalities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Transfer printing technology is a key process in manufacturing film based wearable electronics for the integration of nano-to-microscale materials into functional structures and devices for a wide scope of applications. In transfer printing technologies, patterned materials are first peeled off from a donor substrate and placed onto a receiver substrate. Then the removal of the polymeric mediator finishes the transfer of patterned materials to the target substrate. With the completion of this project, we proposed a series of novel transfer printing approaches in a liquid environment, including capillary mechanics-based transfer, self-delamination of interface driven pattern transfer, electro-chemo-mechanics based transfer, and bubble-driven transfer, and elastocapillary transfer with both translation or rolling motions. The transferred films covers a very broad range of materials including metal, soft polymers and nanomaterials/polymers composites with different structural patterns of both 2D films including graphene and 3D patterned films such as plasmonic films with hole or post pillar arrays. For one example, we proposed the self-delamination transfer approach and completed pattern transfer printing of large-area films, where the self-delamination mechanism is due to the surface wettability of both film and substrate to liquid. The great agreement between them confirms the pattern transfer printing models in a broad range of materials and structures (porous structures with a series of porous densities) of thin films and several types of liquid environments. For another example, we proposed an elastocapillary rolling transfer approach in a liquid substrate surface that enables a fast and facile weave and assembly of soft materials onto 3D curved substrate for spatial structures. The transfer could lead to spatial structures with desirable handedness, weaving orders and arrangements on curved substrates with a broad diversity of geometry shapes including cylinder, sphere and ones with changing curvature for single and multiple forms of soft wire, ribbon and large-area film by controlling rolling direction and orientation and also could produce local structures with ear-like folded shapes by programming transfer directions. We have also developed quantitative mechanics models to reveal the underpinned manufacturing mechanisms of each approach. Theoretical predictions show remarkable agreements with computational and experimental results including results from literatures. For instance, we have established a comprehensive electro-chemo-mechanics theoretical framework of film detachment from various electrode substrates in an electrolyte solution environment. and uncovered the mechanism of interfacial delamination driven by bubble nucleation and growth due to the electrolysis of water, chemical reaction of interfacial materials to liquid or their combination. Parallel to the experimental and theoretical efforts, computational simulations that incorporate theoretical models have also been conducted to analyze the stress/strain of films during transfer processes. The results also offer quantitative comparisons with theoretical predictions and experimental measurements with good agreement, which in turn helps optimize and refine theoretical models and experimental settings. These results have led to 8 peer- reviewed journal publications including Science Advances, Nature Communications, and Advanced Science, and another two manuscripts are currently under preparation including one review manuscript.

The PI and supported PhD students have reported the results through ASME-IMCE conferences and several department seminars. One PhD has finished the PhD degree. PhD students have been awarded Student Poster Travel Award for several times. The PI was invited to write one journal perspective and review articles summarizing the progress in this field of relevance to this project has also awarded 2023 Young Investigator Medal from the Society of Engineering Science. In addition, several undergraduates were involved, and one of them is co-authorized in the review paper. This completion of this project helped the PI build connections with clinical doctor and for potential applications of fabricated devices in human healthcare. The research results of relevance were lectured in graduate-level class MAE 6070 The theory of Elasticity, and has also led to a new undergraduate–level cross-disciplinary special course (ENGR 4595/4599) “Design and Manufacturing of Wearable Electronics” that is offered by PI open to all engineering schools.


Last Modified: 09/03/2023
Modified by: Baoxing Xu
